div1.head: Lacquered Dreams from an Asiatic Screen, by Edward Champe Carter, [19--?]
div1.p:
Lacquered Dreams from an Asiatic Screen.
by
Edward Champe Carter.

lg.l: Pulsing in yellow quietude the river,
Full flowing, deep and swollen from the rains,
Lifts its broad bosom, like a mighty mother
Bearing its children's agonies and pains.
No Beside Close to the western shore bow a little boatlet
Nestles its slender nose among some reeds;
A cat-tail lifts its brown, be-spicéd throatlet--
Close by a sacred crane in quiet feeds.
Within the little boat, a little lady
All brave in satin gown of butter-cup
And jade. The lacquer hair, the black eyes shady,
The pale gold skin--a Goddess' sure make-up!
And in the beauteous hair another yellow
Is fixed by crocus blossoms- Flowery hood!
The dress, the hood, the soft warm skin all mellow
Send out the old world scent of sandal wood.
Her lord, that newly bought her, sits before her,
And idly lets his passion slip aside.
He loves her. Yes, he even may adore her!
But now he lets the boat slip down the tide.
Swiftly across the shimer of the moon-light
A tiny, fretted cloud-puff scurries past.
Warm glows the girl's cheek in this bridal June night,
But stay! Why beats the little heart so fast?
There, in mid-stream, another vessel floating,
Within two ghosts in quietude sit long.
One, her boy lover; with him there a-boating
Nestles the Spirit of his Little Song.
The Lover Boy, in saddest black, is sitting
Close to the stern, one slim hand in the water
Trails gently. And he thinks: “And is it fitting
To show ourselves to her, and him who bought her?”
Pajama clad, in white, the Little Song is;
A happy, jolly, prankish, warm-skinned boy.
Strumming his tiny lute the little Song is,
Filling the youngster heart with tinkled joy
With a song--
Such a boyish song!--
And oh! the lilt of it! The lilt of it!
Whimsical, pathetic, tender,
With a lad's warm-skinnedtoned surrender,
Laughing lightly,
Chaffing slightly,
At its own devotion.
Ending in a childish sigh
Just before the end--to die
On a topaz ocean.
A tear falls from the boat. The little lady
Leans sadly t'ward the Lover and his boating.
So wistfully she gazes, black eyes shady
And wet, all wet! The while the Song goes floating:
“It's lotus time in China-town,
In China-town, my China-town,
Come, Swallow maid, to China-town
Where purple mists are lying!
There on my heart thy head bent low,
Sometimes we'll drift, sometimes we'll row
Pulsing a-down the Hoang-Ho,
A-loving and a-sighing!”
Slowly the night its dusky leave is taking,
Silent the youthful spirits, still a-boating,
The wistful little lady's heart is breaking!
The happy little Song is still a-floating!
Such a song!
Such a boyish song!
And oh! the lilt of it! the lilt of it!
Whimsical, pathetic, tender,
With a lad's warm-toned surrender,
Laughing lightly,
Chaffing slightly,
At its own devotion.
Ending in a childish sigh
Just before the end--to die
On a topaz ocean.
